Graphical abstract Prepared unique mesh-hole structure of VPO catalyst by POM-ILs anions-cations synergetic Interaction for promoting CH bond activation. Vanadyl pyrophosphate (VPO) catalyst exhibits a unique ability to activate CH bond and selectively oxidize n-butane to maleic anhydride (MA). Here, a novel “function-oriented design” strategy was proposed to design and develop single-component additive polyoxometalate-ionic liquids (POM-ILs) with dual-function to enhance the activity of VPO catalyst. And the synergistic interaction of anions and cations of POM-ILs was illuminated combined with characterizations. The IL-cations guide the growth of the catalyst precursor to ordered nanolamellar structure rather than three-dimensional disordered rose-like. Correspondingly, it makes the catalyst exhibit a unique mesh-hole structure and benefit exposure of the active surface (200) of (VO)2P2O7. The POM-anions decompose into the defective OPMo compound and cause more oxygen vacancies and crystal defects formed on the surface of VPO after activation. Besides, we established a specific method to divide the poly-acids (α, β, γ-acid) sites to describe the acidic properties on the surface of VPO by NH3-TPD in qualitatively and quantitatively and related with catalytic performance. Keywords VPO Polyoxometalate-ionic liquids CH bond activation n-Butane oxidation Maleic anhydride Acidity 1 Introduction Vanadyl pyrophosphate (VPO) catalyst exhibits a unique ability to activate CH [1–3] bond and selectively oxidize n-butane to maleic anhydride(MA) [4–6]. The active phase of vanadium phosphoxide catalyst is (VO)2P2O7, which topological transformed from the monoclinic precursor VOHPO4·0.5H2O (VHP) under high-temperature activation. The preparation method significantly affects its structure properties such as crystal structure, crystal phase composition, surface acidity, O-vacancies and dispersion of isolated V5+ sites, correspondingly affect its catalytic performance [7–11]. As known, CH bond activation of low-chain alkanes is the key challenge in oxidize process [12,13]. For VPO catalyst, varieties of additives, single component or parallel components such as Mo, Co, Cd, Zn, Bi, Li, Ni, Cr, Zr, Mg, Nb, Fe, Al, Au, Sm and Ce-Fe were doped to improve its activity, although, the function of the promoters was controversial [14–19]. Hutchings believed that promoters tended to be added transition metal cations in the preparation of the hemihydrate precursor and they pointed out that the function of all these promoters could be classified to electronic promoter and/or structural promoter [20,21]. However, it seemed that almost of researchers were inclined to focus on the effects of metal cations, while their anion was neglected inadvertently, and some anions leaded to poisoning of the catalyst. Simone et al. [22] proposed that in the oxidation of methane when halogen anions, Cl− for instance, were presented during the preparation of the catalyst, charge effects on the precursor complex were incompatible with the carrier surface charges resulting in poor distribution of the salt. Up to now, few people studied the synergistic interaction of anions and cations of the promoters during the preparation of VPO catalyst. In the present work, we proposed a novel “function-oriented design” strategy to design and develop a novel single-component additive with dual-function and reveals its role in promoting the preparation of efficient VPO catalysts in essence for selective oxidation of n-butane. POM-ILs, combining high-valent transition-metal oxo anions (polyoxometalates) and bulky organic cations such as organic ammonium, phosphonium, or imidazolium, have attracted much more attention due to their unique properties such as designable, good oxidizability, thermal stability and acidity [23–27]. Centi et al. [28] used heteropolyacid H5PMo10V2O40 as catalyst for the selectively oxidize n-butane to MA, and thought that the presence of inter-Keggin electron transfer and the existence of the Lewis acid center render the electrons be localized and oxygen vacancies formation. Recently, we found iron-based ILs could work as a structure-directing agents and metal promoter for the synthesis of VPO catalyst to enhance catalytic properties in selective oxidation of n-butane [6]. Inspirited by these research work, we constructed a new dual-functionalized template of POM-ILs by modulating the anions and cations for the promotion of VPO catalyst. In this study, we synthesized a series of POM-ILs containing organic IL-cations and inorganic POM-anions — [TBA]4PMo11VO40 (TBA = tetrabutylammonium), [CTA]4PMo11VO40 (CTA = Cetyltrimethylammonium), [TEBA]4PMo11VO40 (TEBA = Benzyltriethylammonium), [TBA]4PMo12O40, [BMIM]4PMo12O40 (BMIM = 1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium), [TESPA]3PMo12O40 (TESPA = N,N,N-triethyl-3-sulfopropan-1-ammonium), [CTA]3PMo12O40, [TEBA]3PMo12O40 — to promote VPO and investigated their synergistic interaction mechanism (Scheme 1 ). Besides, a specific partition of the poly-acids (α, β, γ-acid) sites was established to describe the acidic properties on the surface of VPO by NH3-TPD. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Preparation of POM-ILs POM-ILs were mainly prepared from keggin-type heteropolyacids and ammonium/imidazole ionic liquids. H4PMo11VO40, H5PMo10V2O40 and Na4PMo11VO40 were prepared according to previous literature [29,30]. Typically, TBACl (0.06 mol) was added to an aqueous solution (150 mL) containing H4PMo11VO40 (0.02 mol). The mixture was stirred vigorously at 60 °C for 12 h in a nitrogen atmosphere. The obtained precipitate was collected by filtration, washed with deionized water and acetone, and then dried overnight to give the final product [TBA]4PMo11VO40 as a light yellow powder. All other POM-ILs (Scheme 2 ), including [TBA]3PMo12O40, [TBA]4PMo11VO40, [TBA]5PMo10V2O40, [TEBA]3PMo12O40, [CTA]3PMo12O40, [TESPA]3PMo12O40, [CTA]4PMo11VO40, [TEBA]4PMo11VO40, and [BMIM]3PMo12O40 were prepared accordingly. The FT-IR of Some POM-ILs are shown in Figure S1. 2.2 Preparation of precursors A precursor was prepared by a two-step synthesis method. V2O5 (0.025 mol) and POM-ILs (atomic ratio Mo/V = 4%) were dissolved together in mixture of iso-butanol (40 mL) and benzyl alcohol (10 mL), then the solution was refluxed for 3 h at 135 °C to form intermediate of precursor (Step 1). Cooled to below 70 °C to add H3PO4 (3.61 mL, wt 85%) and then refluxed for another 16 h at 135 °C (Step 2). The catalyst precursor was collected by filtration, washed with deionized water and ethanol, and then dried 12 h at 100 °C, denoted as POM-ILs@VHP, [TBA]PMoV@VHP, for example. In the same synthesis conditions, without POM-ILs adding was denoted as VHP. 2.3 Preparation of catalysts All the catalysts were prepared from the precursors. Press POM-ILs@VHP into pellets and crush into 20–40 mesh. After that, 2 g POM-ILs@VHP was sealed in the reactor tube, and then the air intake composed of n-butane (1.34%), oxygen (17%) and nitrogen at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 2000 h−1. Heating up to 430 °C at a rate of 2 °C min−1 for 12 h, the precursor was completely transformed to the catalyst, denoted as POM-ILs@VPO, [TBA]PMoV@VPO, for example. Under the same conditions, VHP was activated, denoting as VPO. 2.4 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed with 2θ values between 5° and 60° by using a Rigaku Smart Lab X-ray powder diffractometer employing the graphite filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Ejection of photoelectrons (XPS) measurements were carried out on a ESCALAB 250Xi electron spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific) equipped with 300 W Al Kα radiation source (hν = 1486.6 eV). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured at 77 K using a surface area analyzer (Quanta Chrome Instrument NOVA 2000). All the samples were first degassed at 623 K for 6 h. The surface area was determined by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were acquired using Hitachi SUB8020 instrument, operating at voltage of 5 KV. The elemental compositions were measured by energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) on JEOL-JSM-6301. Raman spectra were recorded by using a Renishaw UV–vis Raman 1000 system equipped with a CCD detector and a Leica DMLM microscope. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was obtained using a Nicolet 380 FTIR spectrometer (Thermal Electron Corporation). Mass spectra (MS) in ESI mode were recorded on a Bruker microTOF-QII spectrometer. Weight loss and phase-transition temperature were conducted via thermogravimetry (TG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) on a Seiko TG/TGA SSC 5000 analyzer. The precursors were heated from ambient temperature to 900 °C at rate of 10 °C min−1. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements (X band) were performed with a JES-RE-1X (JEOL) at room temperature. The resonance frequency, modulation width, and time constant were 9.79 GHz, 0.5 m T, and 2.56 s, respectively. H2-TPR and NH3-TPD experiments were carried out by a Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 apparatus. Prior to the TPR experiments, 30 mg sample was pretreated at 393 K for 1 h under Ar stream (20 mL min−1). After cooling to 323 K, the H2-TPR was performed in 10 vol% H2/Ar (30 mL min−1) to 1123 K with a heating rate of 10 K min−1. NH3, as an alkaline gas, can be combined with the acidic sites on the surface of VPO. So here the NH3-TPD was used to determine the amount of acidity of VPO surface. The physical adsorbed water was desorbed at 393 K for 1 h for pretreatment in air flow, then cooled to 323 K for 1 h until the baseline steady, then the desorption profile was measured by thermal conductivity detector in the He flow at a constant heating rate to 1173 K. To calculate the desorption activation energy, setting different heating rate of 10 K min−1 and 15 K min−1, respectively. 2.5 Catalyst testing Catalytic experiments were carried out in fixed-bed reactor. (Scheme S2) The reaction temperature was 420 °C with 1.34 vol% n-butane under a GHSV of 2000 h−1 until their performance was stabilized (>12 h at least). The output gas of the reactor was analyzed by on-line gas chromatography (shimadzugc-2010). n-butane was analyzed on capillary column (alumina substrate, 30 m) by FID-GC, and CO, CO2 in gaseous product was analyzed by an TCD with TDX-1 column (carbon molecular sieve substrate) and molecular sieve 5a (0.6 m) column. The catalytic performance of conversion of n-butane, MA selectivity, and MA yield, were calculated by the methods used in the reported literature.6 (Equation. S3) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and active phase Morphologies of the samples were characterized by SEM as shown in Fig. 1 . It can be seen that during the reduction of V2O5, the solid substance of intermediate presents a small particle stacking state (Fig. 1a), and then formed the precursor of VHP after the addition of H3PO4, which presents a more regular rosette-like structure (Fig. 1b), activated at high temperature to form fragmented and dense VPO bulk (Fig. 1c) at last. With the addition of [TBA]PMoV, the intermediate of [TBA]PMoV@VHP appeared as a bridge-net (Fig. 1d), and the three-dimensional disordered growth transformed into ordered nanolamellar structures (Fig. 1e) for [TBA]PMoV@VHP, and the platelets of the precursor were smaller and did not agglomerate into sand roses. Followed, a unique three-dimensional mesh-hole nanostructure of [TBA]PMoV @VPO was formed (Fig. 1f). Obviously, the morphology had undergone tremendous changes from the intermediate to the precursor to the catalyst after the addition of [TBA]PMoV (similar changes exist in other types of POM-ILs as shown in Figure S4). Besides, the thickness of the [TBA]PMoV@VPO surface of the mesh-hole structure is very uniform and the lamellar thickness presents volcanic distribution and the average thickness is 21 nm (Fig. 1g). EDS was further carried out and a homogeneous distribution with a small amount of molybdenum was detected (Fig. 1h). XRD analysis identified the monoclinic structure of VOHPO4·0.5H2O with the characteristic peaks (001), (101), (021), (121), (130) and (102) lines at 15.48°, 19.56°, 24.14°, 27.00°, 30.34°, 33.62° for VHP and POM-ILs@VHPs, respectively (Fig. 2 a) [31]. From Fig. 2b, excepting the main characteristic peaks of the standard (VO)2P2O7 (2θ = 22.96°, 28.41°, 29.94°), some peaks are appeared at 19.54°, 22.04°, 28.49°, which can be attributed to the β-VOPO4 phase [31]. It was worth to mention, two weak peaks were detected for POM-ILs@VPH in the range of 6.67°–7.67°, which was related to the heteropolyacid anion crystal phase of the POM-ILs by comparing the XRD spectra of [TBA]PMoV. However, the relative intensity ratio of I(001)/I(130) of the POM-ILs@VHPs was improved (Fig. 2c), especially, the I(001)/I(130) of [TBA]PMoV@VHP leaped to 1.01, which far outclass the VHP (I(001)/I(130) = 0.591). It directly led to an increase in the relative intensity of I(200)/I(013) after activation (Fig. 2c). The (001) plane is topologically transformed to the most critical active plane (200) of (VO)2P2O7. The [TBA]PMoV@VPO powder have a larger BET surface area of 28.28 m2 g−1 compared with that of VPO (17.40 m2 g−1) and HPMoV@VPO (16.31 m2 g−1) as shown in Table 1 . The chemical states of vanadium species on these catalysts were characterized by XPS (Fig. 2d). The main peaks located at around 515 eV and 520 eV were associated with the V 2p3/2. They could be further fitted with two peaks, as shown in Fig. 2d. The two peaks located at 517 eV and 518 eV were associated with V4+ and V5+ oxidation state [32]. The vanadium average valence V ¯ ox and the atomic ratio of P/V as well as molybdenum on the surface of the catalysts were obtained according the XPS analysis. It indicated the promoter POM-ILs and heteropolyacid increase the amount of V5+ to 30.02% and 42.47% respectively, resulting in a higher V ¯ ox related to VPO. It was consistent with the XRD results related to the formation of β-VOPO4. However, [TBA]PMoV@VPO present a lower V ¯ ox and higher the atomic ratio of P/V than that of HPMoV@VPO. 3.2 Synergistic interaction of anions and cations In order to further reveal the synergistic interaction of anions and cations of POM-ILs, FT-IR, Raman, MS, and TGA characterizations was combined. The functional groups of different precursors and [TBA]4PMo11VO40 were detected by FT-IR shown in Fig. 3 a. The precursors of [TBA]PMoV@VHP contains 530 cm−1 Vβ (OPH), 643 cm−1 Vβ (POH), 929 cm−1 Vυ(P(OH)), 982 cm−1 Vυ (VO and PO3 symmetric stretching vibration) and PO3 asymmetric stretching vibration absorption characteristic peak of 1047 cm−1, 1105 cm−1, 1201 cm−1 [34]. In addition, a strong peak appeared at 805 cm−1, and just right asymmetric stretching vibration of Mo-Oc-Mo corresponding to POM-ILs of [TBA]4PMo11VO40 [35]. In Fig. 3b, the FT-IR spectrum of different catalysts shows that there are characteristic absorption peaks of (VO)2P2O7 (1252 cm−1 Vas (PO3), 1089 cm−1 Vs (PO3), 970 cm−1 Vυ (VO), 743 cm−1 Vas(POP), 673 cm−1, 575 cm−1 Vυ(OPO)), [34] yet, the characteristic peak of Mo-Oc-Mo (805 cm−1) disappeared in the keggin structure. Besides, the TG result (Fig. 3d) of the [TBA]4PMo11VO40 shows that the IL-cations decomposed violently at 325 °C, completely decomposed at 342 °C with 23.67% weight loss and the POM-anions decomposed sharply at 416 °C, completely decomposed at 432 °C with 10.68% weight loss. Therefore, it could be considered that the POM-anions still existed during the preparation of the precursor at 135 °C due to its stable Keggin structure, but decomposed into other substance after activation at 430 °C, which was also consistent with the results of XRD (Fig. 2a). A detailed Raman spectra comparison between different catalysts of VPO and H4PMo11VO40 is presented in Fig. 3c. The strong peaks of 932 cm−1 and 994 cm−1 represent the vibrational peaks of Va(POP) and Vs(VO) of (VO)2P2O7, respectively, and the β-VOPO4 can be determined as well [36]. Mentioned in FT-IR, the POM-ILs@VPO of characteristic peaks of Mo-Oc-Mo (805 cm−1) disappears. For further exploring the POM-anions phase transformation process, we exam the a heteropolyacid (H4PMo11VO40) for contrast, at 845 cm−1 and 1019 cm−1, corresponds to the vibrational peaks of Vas (Mo-Ob-Mo) and Vs (Mo-Od). After activation and evaluation, POM-ILs@VPO and HPMoV@VPO catalysts showed two peaks between 980-1024 cm−1, meanwhile, only one peak in VPO. It can be reckoned the different peak represented in POM-ILs@VPO and HPMoV@VPO catalysts due to the decomposition of the POM-anions, and the substance contains MoOd bond. The MoOP bond peaks in the heteropolyacid structure are assigned to 985 cm−1, 997 cm−1 and 1073 cm−1, which coincides with the characteristic peaks of β-VOPO4. Zhou et al. 34 used thermogravimetry to analyze the thermal decomposition process of H4PMo11VO40 and concluded that it would be decomposed into a highly defective PMo6O10 compound between 300 °C and 400 °C, which would be completely decomposed into MoO3, V2O5 and P2O5 at temperatures more than 430 °C. If MoO3 is finally formed, its highly symmetrical MoOMo bond and OMoO will appear strong characteristic peaks at 809 cm−1 and 655 cm−1. Note that there is no corresponding peak in our catalysts. Therefore, it suggested that the POM-anions decomposes into the defective O-P-Mo compound loading on the surface of the VPO catalyst after activation. In the investigation of n-butane selective oxidation, the mechanism of OPM (M = metal) activation of CH reaction was proposed. The oxo activated groups (proton receptors) and the metals (electron receptors) are separated from each other by interacting atoms (P), making them more independent and optimized than that in metal-oxo systems [37]. Goddard et al. found that OP on the VVOPO4surface is the active center for initiating the VPO chemistry through extraction of H from alkane CH bonds, and speculate that H abstraction by OP, with trapping of the hydrocarbyl radical on OV, while a second H abstraction by another OP [4]. Thus, it is assumed that OPV and OPMo cooperatively participate in the abstraction of H of CH bond and accelerate transfers electrons. OP bond transform into POH and the metal atom is reduced by an electron. [2,38,39] In order to investigate the role of IL-cations group, we took the [TBA]PMoV promoter as an example and characterized the homogeneous solution after the reduction reaction of V2O5 with alcohol solvent (step 1) and that after the addition of H3PO4 (step 2) during the preparation of precursor by MS. It was found that whether after step 1 or step 2, the cation of [TBA]PMoV was detected as itself of N(C(CH3)3)4 + (shown in Figure S5). [TBA]PMoV did not decompose in the homogeneous solution due to its stability, but some cations groups of N(C(CH3)3)4 + released into the solution because of the effect of the solvent and guided the transformation process of the precursor. In the step 1, the free N(C(CH3)3)4 + led to V2O5 formation with a bridge-network intermediate (Fig. 1d). After the addition of H3PO4 (step 2), N(C(CH3)3)4 + continue to guide the bridge-network intermediate into an ordered nanolamellar structure (Fig. 1e). In order to further to illuminate the effect of TBA cations, we added N(CH2CH2CH2CH3)4Br with same molar ratio alone in step 1 to prepare precursor, denoting as TBA@VHP. Similar phenomenon appeared as [TBA]PMoV@VHP shown in Figure S6. Thus, it can be assumed IL-cations play a significant role in the guidance of structure. Because the transition structure of the precursor promoted by [TBA]PMoV had changed greatly that the catalyst exhibiting a unique three-dimensional mesh-hole structure after activation. Based on these findings, we propose the synergistic interaction mechanism of anions and cations in preparation of VPO catalysts promoted with POM-ILs (Scheme 1). The free IL-cations lead the transition of the catalyst precursor, from the original three-dimensional disordered rose-like growth to the ordered nanolamellar structures, makes the catalyst exhibit a unique mesh-hole structure and enhances exposure of the active surface (200) of (VO)2P2O7. The POM-anions are decomposed into O-P-Mo compound with a defective structure, loading on the surface of the VPO catalyst, as molybdenum was detected by XPS and EDS analysis on the surface of VPO. And O = P-Mo can cooperate with OPV to accelerate electrons transmission rate. 3.3 Oxygen vacancies and crystal defects Fig. 4 a shows the H2-TPR profile of different catalysts. The values of the activation energies for reduction (Er) of the synthesized catalysts by reduction gas, Er have been calculated using Redhead equation [40]. (Equation S7) E r R T m 2 = A r β H 2 m exp - E r R T m All the catalysts were found to have three reduction peaks and the Er and the total amount of oxygen atoms being removed from different catalysts were calculated and summarized in Table 2 . As for VPO, the total amount of oxygen removed was 1.92 × 1021 atom g−1 with 0.685 × 1021, 0.755 × 1021 and 0.479 × 1021 atom g-1 for peaks at 826 K, 1030 K and 1107 K, respectively. Two reduction peaks for HPMoV@VPO were observed shifted to lower temperatures at 812 K and 974 K, and the amount of oxygen species removed were tremendously increased to 2.25 × 1021 atom g−1. As the [TBA]PMo@VPO, the reduction peaks were obviously shifted to lower temperatures of 802 K and 946 K. It is worth mentioning that the amount of oxygen removed from the first peak has a sharply drop to 0.404 × 1021 atom·g−1 whereas the amount of oxygen atoms removed from latter peak increased to 0.759 × 1021and 1.39 × 1021 atom g−1 for peaks at 946 K and 1106 K, respectively, making the total amount of oxygen species removed evidently improve to 2.55 × 1021 atom g−1. These results suggested [TBA]PMo@VPO possesses more oxygen vacancies and oxygen active sites and accompanied with lower reduction peak temperature and Er. The EPR spectra of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 4b. All VPO catalysts display a single line centered around giso = 1.960 which is related to V(IV), without resolved hyperfine structure [15]. The absence of hyperfine structure corresponding to V is common in solid state VPO catalysts and is attributed to the strong interference of neighboring electron spins, which is related to high (VO)2+ cation concentration in the structure [41,42]. The amount of unit volume of electron deficient pairs is calculated and shown in Fig. 4c. [TBA]PMoV@VPO showed a strong intensity of electron paramagnetic resonance and can reach an electron deficient pairs amount of 1.39 × 1018 mm−3, while 9.21 × 1017  mm−3 for VPO. One or more electrons or holes are trapped in or near the defect to form a single electron substance. There is no single electron and no EPR signal peak when molybdenum is pentavalent in [TBA]PMoV. As mentioned above, OPMo compounds with serious defects were formed by thermal decomposition of [TBA]PMoV, and other valence molybdenum might be formed in the defect structure. Beside, highly defective molybdenum compounds were loaded on the surface of VPO, and the molybdenum and vanadium metal elements might exchange electrons and form more electron holes, thus increasing the electron deficient pairs content and more crystal defects formed. The increase of electron deficient pairs and crystal defects can accelerate the electron transmission rate and make electrons transfer more efficiently in the O = P-M activation. 3.4 Surface acidic property Fig. 4d shows the NH3-TPD profile of different catalysts and the results is listed in Table 3 . The desorption activation energies (Ed) were obtained through the TPR fundamental equation [43] (Equation S8) 2 ln T m - ln σ = E d R T m + C C = ln E d V m R K d VPO has complex crystal structure and mutil-acid sites, while, the definition of surface acidic sites is still vague. Some researchers used pyrimidine infrared method to divide acidic sites to Lewis-Brønsted (L-B) acid (< 623 K assigned to Lewis- acid site, > 623 K assigned to Brønsted) on the surface of VPO. Nevertheless, it can’t obtain surface acidic amount. NH3-TPD, has been widely used in the determination of acidity on the surface of catalytic materials because of its ability to characterize different acid sites as well as the measurement of acid amount [44,45]. However, the explanation of result with NH3-TPD was vague, especially the division of the acid sites, Lewis-Brønsted acid in pyridine infrared method are often used indistinctly [17,46,47]. From Fig. 4d and Table 3, we can observe that all the three catalysts showed only one peak below 473 K and their Ed are close to 2.3 kJ mol−1, 3.8 kJ mol−1 and 4.0 kJ mol−1. During 473 K–773 K, the Tm peaks appeared at 615 K, 634 K and 644 K respectively, and the corresponding Ed are 19.6 kJ mol−1,22.9 kJ mol−1, 27.7 kJ mol−1. When the temperature is above 773 K, also only one Tm peak appears, the Ed are 177.8 kJ mol−1, 114.7 kJ mol−1, 135.7 kJ mol−1. In order to clarify the acid property on the surface of VPO clearly and intuitively, we reclassified the acidic sites according to Tm and Ed as well, like – other metal oxide such as Al2O3 and ZSM-5 [48–50]. Accordingly, shown in Table 3, here we defined the low temperature desorption peak between 273 K and 473 K as the weak acid sites called α-acid, in the range of 473 K and 773 K defined as the medium acid sites called β-acid and above 773 K as the strong acid sites called γ -acid. Obviously, the total acid amount of [TBA]PMoV@VPO can reach up to 14.9 × 1021 atom g−1, which is much higher than that of HPMoV@VPO (8.67 × 1021 atom g−1) and VPO (8.49 × 1021 atom g−1) as shown in Fig. 4e. Moreover, the amount of β-acid increase with γ -acid decrease in three catalysts, especially for [TBA]PMoV@VPO. Interestingly, we found there is a positive correlation between the amount of α-acid and oxygen vacancies linearly (Fig. 4f). It is suggested that the α-acid maybe relevant to the structural defects and it is reasonable to divide the acid sites in this way. For β-acid, it is assumed to unsaturated vanadium(IV) ions exposed on the surface coupled to VO bonds due to the increase of V5+ amount. As the γ -acid may be attributed to the presence of POH or VOH groups on the surface. [8,34,51] 3.5 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of POM-ILs@VPO was evaluated for selective oxidation of n-butane to MA and the effect of cations and anions as well as some important reaction parameters was investigated in detail (Fig. 5 ). Compared with other promoter of proton heteropolyacid (HPMoV) and metal heteropolyacid salt (NaPMoV), [TBA]PMoV@VPO showed a enhancement in conversion of n-butane and yield of MA (Fig. 5a). A 95.2% of conversion was achieved, which is 15% higher than that of VPO. HPMoV@VPO also exhibited high conversion, but 8% yield lower than [TBA]PMoV@VPO, over oxidation occurred at the expense of MA selectivity obviously. NaPMoV@VPO showed a decrease in conversion (63.3%) and yield (38.8%) maybe because of the alkali metal Na poisoned the surface of VPO. n-Butane molecules, as saturated fatty hydrocarbons, are difficult to dehydrogenate and require strong acid sites to activate CH bond, but the acid strength of V4+ on the (200) plane of (VO)2P2O7 was not enough. It was assumed the proper amount of β-VOPO4 phase presented in [TBA]PMoV@VPO and HPMoV@VPO is benefit for the activation of CH bond, as seen from XRD and Raman characterization. β-VOPO4 phase embedded in (VO)2P2O7 crystal lattice takes advantage of its strong acid sites and synergized the interaction of V5+ on (VO)2P2O7 (200) plane promote the dehydrogenation of n-butane. However, excess V5+ caused butane over oxidize to CO and CO2, [52] causing n-butane conversion increased, while MA yield decreased, such like HPMoV@VPO owing 42.47% of V5+ from XPS. The addition of [TBA]PMo and HPMoV increased the amount of oxygen vacancies and crystal defects from H2-TPR and EPR, which can enhance molecular oxygen reservation and the electron transmission, making CH bond activation efficiently. As known, a proper acid site is required to activate CH bond, especially for the rate control step of the dehydrogenation of butane to butane [53]. From NH3-TPD results, the total acid amounts of β-acid in POM-ILs@VPO were higher and the γ-acid was dramatic lower than that of VPO. Notably, the amount of γ-acid is highest with β-acid lowest for VPO. Different acid sites can play different roles in the reaction. Centi et al. thought that weak acid sites associated with structural defects should be considered as the active sites for C4 activation and strong acid sites participate in selective producing of MA [54,55]. Consequently, we believed that the n-butane could be activated and desorb properly from the medium β-acid sites on the surface of VPO, so that the dehydrogenation process proceeds smoothly. The strong γ-acid sites participate more in the electron transfer and reconstruction, making the selective oxidation reaction efficient. Accordingly, all those is responsible for the higher activity appears over [TBA]PMoV@VPO compared to VPO in selective oxidation of n-butane. As for the effect of IL-cations groups and POM-anions, we chose the typical kegging structure POM-anions – PMo12O40 3−, PMo11VO40 4- and [PMo10V2]5 (Fig. 5b), and varies the functional groups and chain length of cations of ILs (Fig. 5c,d). It is interesting to find that the amine cations showed better promoting effect than imidazole cations and the length of the cation chain was negative against the conversion of n-butane, resulting in a positive correlation with the MA selectivity. It might be that the amine cations have stronger surface tension, which can effectively guide the transformation of the precursor and expose more active phase. For long-chain functional group, it is not easy to enter the structure gap, so that the guiding effect is weakened. As for POM-anions, it is found that they all showed high conversion of n-butane and high MA yield with the same cations [TBA]-, but lower MA selectivity due to over oxidation especially for [PMo10V2]5-, only 50.8% MA selectivity. In order to understand the synergistic interaction of anions and cations of POM-ILs, we took [TBA]4PMo11VO40 as an example for further investigation. Instead of adding [TBA]4PMo11VO40 during the preparation of the catalyst precursor VHP, we mixed 4% [TBA]4PMo11VO40 with the obtained VHP without promoter physically, referred as [TBA]PMoV-VPO (mixture) (Fig. 5e). Like HPMoV@VPO, the physical mixture enhanced the conversion of n-butane dramatically but caused ever worse over oxidation. From the SEM characterization mentioned above, we can see that the free IL-cations group can affect growth behavior of VHP when added [TBA]4PMo11VO40 during the in-situ synthesis of VHP. It can change its morphology and modify the surface properties of VPO such as oxygen vacancies and acidity after activation, correspondingly, resulting a good catalytic performance. However, for [TBA]PMoV-VPO, mechanical mixing does not directly affect the microscopic morphology of the catalyst and the active site distribution of the precursor. In addition, we optimized the addition amount of [TBA]4PMo11VO40 with different Mo/V atomic ratio ranging from 2% to 8% (Fig. 5e). The preferred doping amount is 4–6% a with a high yield of MA and less COx emission. Further, we investigated the effect of the reaction temperature over [TBA]PMoV@VPO in selective oxidation of n-butane. The conversion and selectivity curve with time under different temperatures of 380 °C, 400 °C and 420 °C, are shown in Fig. 5f. Obviously, the conversion increase as the reaction temperature increase, inversely the selectivity to MA. It is worth to mention, [TBA]PMoV@VPO showed much better catalytic performance under low temperature. The conversion of n-butane can reach above 83% with a high MA selectivity (66%) when the reaction was carried out under 380 °C. Recently, Grasselli and Trifirò summarized and pointed out that with the VPO catalysts reported until now, the best molar yields of MA was ranged between 57 and 65 mol% at an n-butane conversion of 80–85 mol% under extreme high temperature, above 400 °C [56]. Thus, POM-ILs@VPO catalyst can be considered as a promising catalyst for the oxidation of n-butane to MA, which is the most successful example of activation of light alkanes to valuable chemicals, from the point of economy and environmental. 4 Conclusion The present work investigated the synergistic interaction of anions and cations of POM-ILs during the preparation of VPO catalysts for selective oxidation of n-butane to MA. The characterization analysis reveal that during the preparation of the precursor, free IL-cations is released into the homogeneous solvent, guiding the growth of the precursor. Bulk V2O5 was first reduced to a bridge-net POM-ILs@VHP intermediate, formed an ordered nanolamellar structures of POM-ILs@VHP after H3PO4 addition, and finally making the POM-ILs@VPO catalyst exhibit a unique mesh-hole structure and enhances exposure of the active surface (200) of (VO)2P2O7. The POM-anions, plays a significant role in the activation stage, decomposes into the defective structure OPMo compound loading on the surface of the VPO catalyst. And the OP-Mo formed promotes the activation of C–H bond in coordination with O P–V. Compared with VPO, NaPMoV@VPO and HPMoV@VPO, [TBA]PMoV@VPO achieved the best catalytic performance, 95.2% of n-butane conversion and 58.3% of the yield of MA under the same reaction conditions. It was found POM-ILs@VPO catalysts exhibited lower Tmax and Er accompanied with higher amount of oxygen vacancies, and highly defective molybdenum compounds derived from POM-anions possessing more deficient electron pairs and crystal defect on the surface. All these facilities the activation of C–H bond in n-butane and resulted in high conversion. Besides, the poly-acids center of catalysts surface was divided into α, β, γ-acidic according to Tm and Ed with NH3-TPD to describe the surface acidic properties in qualitatively and quantitatively and related with catalytic performance. Proper acidity is favorable to dehydrogenation of n-butane, and its α-acid site can be assigned to structure defects according to the linear relationship with O vacancies. coredata.dc:description: Vanadyl pyrophosphate (VPO) catalyst exhibits a unique ability to activate CH bond and selectively oxidize n-butane to maleic anhydride (MA). Here, a novel “function-oriented design” strategy was proposed to design and develop single-component additive polyoxometalate-ionic liquids (POM-ILs) with dual-function to enhance the activity of VPO catalyst. And the synergistic interaction of anions and cations of POM-ILs was illuminated combined with characterizations. The IL-cations guide the growth of the catalyst precursor to ordered nanolamellar structure rather than three-dimensional disordered rose-like. Correspondingly, it makes the catalyst exhibit a unique mesh-hole structure and benefit exposure of the active surface (200) of (VO)2P2O7. The POM-anions decompose into the defective OPMo compound and cause more oxygen vacancies and crystal defects formed on the surface of VPO after activation. Besides, we established a specific method to divide the poly-acids (α, β, γ-acid) sites to describe the acidic properties on the surface of VPO by NH3-TPD in qualitatively and quantitatively and related with catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: Synergistic interaction of anions and cations in preparation of VPO catalysts promoted by polyoxometalate-ionic liquids
